ORDER
Dated this the 7th day of January 2020

The petitioners have been directed to show
cause why they should not execute a bond under
Section 107 of the Cr.P.C as per impugned order
at Annexure-I.

2. The order indicates that, on a report
filed by the Sub Inspector of Police consequent
to registering an FIR as Crime No.232/19 under
Section 107 of the Cr.P.C, the Sub Divisional
Magistrate was convinced that the petitioners
are liable to answer for breach of peace
because earlier, another Crime No.79/2019 has
been registered against them. Accordingly the
impugned order was issued. It is pertinent to
note that even though Annexure Al indicate that
it was a preliminary order it is not an order
under Section 111. Even though, towards the end
of the order, the Sub Divisional Magistrate

2020/KER/502
Crl.MC.No.8272 OF 2019(D)
3

states that the petitioners shall show cause
why they should not be ordered under Section
107 of the Cr.P.C r/w Section 111 of the said
code to execute a bond for Rs.25,000/- with two
solvent sureties for a like amount to keep
peace for a period of one year, no. such
combined order can be passed by the Sub
Divisional Magistrate as it is held by this
Court in Santhosh v. State of Kerala, 2014 (3)
KLT 837 and also subsequent decision in
Sajeesh.K v. State of Kerala, 2014 SCC Online
Ker.27899. By initiating proceedings under
Section 107 of the Cr.P.C, the Magistrate must
pass an order under Section 111 of the Cr.P.C,
stating the nature of information proceedings
and the relevant factors which influence the
mind in Magistrate to form an opinion that the
petitioners are likely to cause imminent breach
of peace or public tranquility in a particular

2020/KER/502
Crl.MC.No.8272 OF 2019(D)
4
case and the probable period during which it is
likely to disturb the peace of tranquility ina
particular locality, and in order to prevent
the same it is necessary to take preventive
actions against them.

3. In the instant case apart from the FIR
which was registered by the Sub Inspector which
itself appears to be not proper because Section
107 of the Cr.P.C is not a cognizable offence
for which an FIR can be registered. It should
actually has been a report filed by the Sub
Inspector of Police requesting action to be
taken under Section 107 of the Cr.P.C.

4. In view of the settled position that
proceedings under Section 111 has to be
initiated prior to making an order under
Section 107 and therefore, the entire
proceedings in Annexure-I as M.C No.217/2019,

against the petitioners shall stands quashed.

However, it is made clear that there is no
embargo in the Sub Divisional Magistrate
proceeding afresh on a report properly received
in accordance with law.
